intro: Syngonanthus savannarum var. glabrescens, commonly known as the smooth sand-verbena, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It is characterized by its slender, erect stems and small, clustered flowers that range in color from white to pink. The plant typically grows in sandy or well-drained soils, often in open habitats such as sand dunes or coastal areas. It has a low-growing habit with narrow, linear leaves that are usually hairless. This variety is noted for its ecological importance in stabilizing sandy soils and providing nectar for pollinators.
